metadata.Title: CVE-2013-NNN1 on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (trusty) - low.
metadata.Description:
The mysql-5.5 package misses the patches applied previous in Debian's mysql-5.1 to drop the database "test" and the permissions that allow anonymous access, without a password, from localhost to the "test" database and any databases starting with "test_". This update reintroduces these patches for the mysql-5.5 package.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2013-NNN1` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

libmysqlclient18 - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
libmysqld-pic - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-client - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-client-5.5 - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-client-core-5.5 - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-common - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-server - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-server-5.5 - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-server-core-5.5 - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-source-5.5 - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-testsuite - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
mysql-testsuite-5.5 - 5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1
No subscription required

notes.Note: jdstrand> Running mysql_secure_installation (generally recommended for production environments) will prompt to remove the 'test' database Affects new installations of mysql-5.5, not upgrades from mysql-5.1 and the Debian patch does not remove the 'test' database on upgrades (to prevent data loss).

criterions.comment: mysql-5.5 package in trusty, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '5.5.35+dfsg-1ubuntu1').
